data.title: heads of state
data.text:
years image name(s), birth- and death data and political party title and reign

From the 6th to the 10th century, Poland had several legendary dukes, of which the last four are semi-legendary in this list: 6th century Lech I Founder of the Polish Nation:

6th century 8th century Krak I Founder of KrakÃ³w:

8th century 8th century Krak II Leader of KrakÃ³w:

8th century 8th century Lech II Leader of KrakÃ³w:

8th century 8th century Wanda Daughter of Krak I:

8th century 7th/8th century Leszko I Duke of the Goplanes and the Polans:

7th/8th century 8th century Leszko II Duke of the Polans:

8th century 8th century Leszko III Duke of the Polans:

8th century 8th century Popiel I Duke of the Polans:

8th century 9th century Popiel II Duke of the Polans:

9th century 9th century Piast KoÅodziej (the Weelwright), died in 861 of 870. Duke of the Polans:

9th century 90?-92? Siemowit, born 8?? and died 92?. Duke of Poland:

90? - 92? 92?-94? Leszek, died about 94? Duke of Poland:

92? - 94? 94?-95? SiemomysÅ, died about 95?. Duke of Poland:

94? - 95?

After Duke Mieszko I, BolesÅaw I became the first king of Poland. Mieszko II succeeded him as duke but shortly afterwards also proclaimed himself king. After him, Poland became a duchy again, with the exception or 1076-1079 when BolesÅaw II proclaimed himself king again. It is a time of many divisions and invasions in the Greater Poland area. The dukes and kings until 1138: 963-992 Mieszko I, born about 920/945 and died on 25 May 992 in Poznań, about 46 to 71 years old. Duke of Poland:

963 - 25-05-992 992-1025 Bolesław I Chrobry (the Brave) or Wielki (the Great), born in 966 or 967 in Poznań and died on 17 June 1025 in KrakÃ³w, about 57 to 59 years old. Duke of Poland:

25-05-992 - 18-04-1025

King of Poland:

18-04-1025 - 17-06-1025 1025-1031 Mieszko II Lambert (the Fat), born about 990 and died on 10 May 1034 in PoznaÅ, about 43 years old. Duke of Poland:

17-06-1025 - 25-12-1025

King of Poland:

??-11-1031 - ??-09-1032 1032 Dytryk, born after 992 and died after 1032, at least 40 years old. Pretender:

??-11-1031 - ??-09-1032 1032-1033 Otto BolesÅawowic, born about 1000 and died in 1033, about 33 years old. Pretender:

??-09-1032 - 10-05-1034 1034-1038/9 Bolesław Zapomniany (the Forgotten) of Okrutny (the Cruel). Semi-legendary Duke, born before 1016 and died in 1038 or 1039, about 20 to 22 years old. Duke of Poland (disputed):

10-05-1034 - 1038/1039 1039-1058 Kazimierz I Odnowiciel (the Restorer), born on 25 July 1016 in KrakÃ³w and died on 28 November 1058 in PoznaÅ, 42 years old. Duke of Poland:

10-05-1039 - 28-11-1058 1058-1079 Bolesław II Śmiały (the Bald), Sycyodrz (the Generous) of Okrutny (the Bold), born about 1043 and died on 2 or 3 April 1081 or 1082 in Ossiach, Austria, about 37 years old. Duke of Poland:

28-11-1058 - 25-12-1076

King of Poland:

25-12-1076 - ??-06-1079 1079-1102 Władisław I Herman, born about 1044 and died on 4 June 1102 in PÅock, about 57 years old. Duke of Poland:

??-06-1079 - 04-06-1102 1102-1107 Zbigniew, born about 1073 and died probably on 8 July 1113 in Tyniec, about 40 years old. Duke of Poland with BolesÅaw III:

1107 - 28-10-1138

The will of BolesÅaw III led to a fragmentation of territories in the Duchy, with the Grand Duke of Poland being the preeminent leader: 1138-1146 Władisław II Wygnaniec (the Exile), born about 1105 in KrakÃ³w and died on 30 May 1159 in Altenburg, Germany, about 53 years old. Grand Duke of Poland:

In 1295 PrzemysÅ I became king of Poland and a rapprochement was sought with Bohemia. After Duke WÅadisÅaw I, Poland again became a kingdom in personal union with Bohemia. From 1306 onwards it was a duchy again, with many pretenders joining in, but Henryk IV and WÅadisÅaw I being the actual dukes from 1309 onwards: 1295-1296 Przemysł I, born on 14 October 1257 in Poznań and died on 8 February 1296 in Rogoźno, 38 years old. The kings of Poland from 1320 onwards were systematically interrupted by an interrex, a kind of intermediate king, who determined who would become the next king. 1320-1333 Władisław I Łokietek (the Short), born between 3 March 1260 and 19 January 1261 and died on 2 March 1333 in KrakÃ³w, 72 years old. After the third partition by Prussia and Russia, Poland disappeared completely from the map. In 1806, with the help of France, an attempt was made to give the country an identity again. The following year the Duchy of Warsaw was created. It had a short-lived existence. In 1815 the Kingdom of Poland was restored again, but with the Russian Tsar as leader, briefly interrupted by the uprising or 1831-1832. 1806-1807 Louis Nicolas d'Avout (Davout), born on 10 May 1770 in Annoux, France and died on 1 June 1823 in Paris, France, 53 years old.

In 1915, the Russians were expelled and the country was occupied by Germany and Austria. Two years later it was declared a kingdom again under the protection of the aforementioned countries, although only representatives of the king were in power (from 1917 onwards, Niemojowski). The actual king was never installed, because the republic was proclaimed in 1921 under PiÅsudski after the end of the Polish-Soviet war through the Treaty of Riga. In 1918, Poland had already ended ties with Germany and Austria. 1915-1918 Hans Hartwig von Beseler, born on 27 April 1850 in Greifswald, Germany and died on 20 December 1921 in Potsdam, Germany, 71 years old. Although according to the letter Wieniawa was the first president in exile. Since he was unable to succeed MoÅcicki after he fled to Romania in 1939, Wieniawa is often left out of the list of presidents. In 1939, Rackiewicz was declared the first president in exile outside Poland. The position remained in the United Kingdom until a year after the collapse of communist Poland, after which this republic became redundant and the country was free again.
